title: Evacuations ordered as Black Fire burns thousands of acres in Tonto National Forest
summary: Evacuations are ongoing as the Black Fire, sparked by lightning, has consumed over 11,100 acres in Tonto National Forest and is currently 85% contained. Several communities and recreation areas in Tonto Basin are under evacuation orders, while additional areas are on standby for potential evacuation. A call center has been set up to assist affected residents, and a virtual public meeting will provide updates on the situation. Key forest areas remain closed, and extensive firefighting resources, including personnel and equipment, are being deployed to manage the blaze.

title: Arizona attorney general calls on FEMA to recognize extreme heat, wildfire smoke as disasters
summary: Arizona Attorney General Kris Mayes, along with 13 other state attorneys general, is urging FEMA to classify extreme heat and wildfire smoke as major disasters due to their increasing severity linked to climate change. The letter highlights the alarming rise in heat-related deaths and wildfires in Arizona, emphasizing the health risks associated with wildfire smoke. Experts stress the need for federal support to enhance community resources and protections against these escalating environmental challenges.

title: Davenport firefighter reflects on the 35th anniversary of the Loma Prieta Earthquake
summary: The article commemorates the 35th anniversary of the Loma Prieta earthquake, which struck Santa Cruz County and the Bay Area on October 17, 1989, causing significant destruction and resulting in 63 fatalities. With a magnitude of 6.9, the earthquake displaced over 12,000 people and injured nearly 3,800. Residents shared their memories of the chaos and devastation, highlighting communication failures and extensive property damage. Former firefighter Philip Arro also recounted his experiences during the disaster.

title: Watch Fire 100% contained after burning over 2,000 acres in eastern Arizona
summary: The Watch Fire on the San Carlos Apache Indian Reservation in eastern Arizona is now 100% contained after burning 2,162 acres and destroying at least 13 homes, leaving 75 people homeless. Over 400 residents were evacuated, and officials are investigating arson as the potential cause. Firefighters are patrolling the area, and residents are advised to avoid burned structures due to health hazards. The situation has deeply affected the community, with many individuals, like Sheila Patton, expressing their heartbreak over the loss of homes and belongings.

title: Multiple fire agencies responding to a fire in the riverbed near San Lorenzo Park
summary: Multiple fire agencies, including Cal Fire, are responding to a wildfire near San Lorenzo Park, dubbed the Broadway Fire, which has spread to five acres in the riverbed area. Firefighters are currently facing challenges in accessing the site, and the public is advised to avoid the area as crews work to extinguish the flames. This situation is ongoing and developing.

title: Semi-trailer catches fire Thursday morning prompting the State Park Dr. off-ramp to close, now reopened; CHP
summary: A semi-trailer fire on Thursday morning led to the temporary closure of the northbound Highway 1 State Park Dr. off-ramp in Santa Cruz, California. The California Highway Patrol (CHP) announced that the ramp has since reopened, and cleaning crews were dispatched to clear debris from the accident site.

title: Fire doesn’t always spell disaster, Santa Cruz County agencies hold first-ever Good Fire Fair
summary: The first-ever Central Coast Good Fire Fair took place at Henry Cowell Redwoods State Park in Felton, California, aimed at educating the public about the beneficial role of fire in California's landscapes. Despite a planned demonstration burn being canceled due to heat alerts, officials discussed the importance of prescribed burns for ecological health and community safety. Attendees engaged in various interactive activities, learning about defensible space and the significance of proper burning practices. The event emphasized the need for greater public awareness of prescribed burns and their environmental benefits.

title: Fire doesn’t always spell disaster, Santa Cruz County agencies hold first-ever Good Fire Fair
summary: The first-ever Central Coast Good Fire Fair was held at Henry Cowell Redwoods State Park in Felton, California, to educate the public on the importance of fire in local ecosystems. Santa Cruz County agencies emphasized the benefits of prescribed burns and the need for communities to understand fire management. Although a planned demonstration burn was canceled due to heat alerts, various educational activities were conducted to highlight safe burning practices and the ecological benefits of fire.

title: Davenport firefighter reflects on the 35th anniversary of the Loma Prieta Earthquake
summary: The article commemorates the 35th anniversary of the Loma Prieta earthquake, which struck Santa Cruz County and the Bay Area on October 17, 1989, causing around $10 billion in damage and resulting in 63 fatalities. Residents, including former firefighter Philip Arro, shared their harrowing experiences during the quake, which left homes and businesses damaged and disrupted communication. The quake, measured at a magnitude of 6.9, led to chaos in Santa Cruz, with people recounting how the earthquake shook their homes and caused widespread panic.

title: Multi-audience wildfire survey shows gaps in wildfire risk reduction education and access to resources
summary: A national survey by the Fire Protection Research Foundation revealed significant gaps in wildfire risk reduction education among homeowners and renters, with only half aware of how to mitigate risks and just 43% knowing where to access resources. Conducted in California and Oregon, the survey emphasized the need for improved education and access to wildfire prevention information. While 79% of residents expressed some motivation to learn more about mitigation methods, only a small percentage were aware of available government incentives. The report calls for increased efforts to motivate residents to take action against wildfire threats.

title: Santa Cruz County secures $1 million grant for enhanced wildfire prevention measures
summary: Santa Cruz County has received a $1 million grant from the state to enhance wildfire prevention efforts, particularly along the Soquel-San Jose road, which is a key evacuation route. This funding aims to improve safety and infrastructure following the devastating CZU fires four years ago. The grant will support hazardous fuel reduction treatments and provide chipping services for residents to create defensible spaces around their homes, ultimately helping to protect neighborhoods and facilitate rapid access for first responders during wildfires.

title: Apex Fire burns 3,100 acres southwest of Grand Canyon; 40% contained
summary: The Apex Fire in northern Arizona has burned approximately 3,100 acres, located about 23 miles southwest of the Grand Canyon, and is currently 40% contained. Firefighters are battling the blaze, which is being fueled by pinyon pine, juniper, and sagebrush, with around 50 personnel on the scene and additional resources requested. Although the fire is producing thick smoke visible to nearby communities, it is not currently threatening any structures. The cause of the fire remains unknown.

title: Two pets die in house fire in Santa Cruz, no civilian or firefighter injuries reported, firefighters say
summary: A house fire in Santa Cruz early Sunday morning resulted in the tragic deaths of two pets, a cat and a bird. The Santa Cruz Fire Department responded to the fully engulfed two-story home on Westmoor Court, where two adults had already evacuated safely. Firefighters were able to contain the blaze, preventing it from spreading to nearby homes, but most of the second story was destroyed. The cause of the fire is still under investigation, and the affected residents have family nearby to stay with. No injuries were reported among civilians or firefighters.

title: San Carlos Apache Tribe resident sees destroyed home after wildfire ripped through community
summary: Sheila Patten returned to her property in the San Carlos Apache Indian Reservation to find her home destroyed by the Watch Fire, which is suspected to be arson. The fire devastated over 2,000 acres, destroying numerous homes and forcing hundreds to evacuate. Sheila, who lived in the family home for nearly 60 years, lost her belongings and a pet cat, but she and her family are currently staying together in an evacuation center. A fundraiser has been established to support her family as they cope with the loss and hope to rebuild in the future.

title: United Food Bank launches emergency initiative to help San Carlos in aftermath of Watch Fire
summary: The United Food Bank has initiated an emergency program to assist the San Carlos Apache Tribe in Arizona after the Watch Fire left 75 people homeless and destroyed 13 homes. The nonprofit will provide food and clean drinking water through its USDA and Pantry+ programs, delivering emergency food boxes to those unable to access distribution sites. The fire, suspected to be caused by arson, has burned 2,162 acres and is currently 81% contained. Arizona Governor Katie Hobbs has allocated $400,000 to support the tribal community, and federal funds have also been authorized for firefighting efforts.

title: Kitchen fire breaks out in unoccupied Santa Cruz home Friday morning
summary: A kitchen fire broke out in an unoccupied home on Westmoor Court and Westmoor Drive in Santa Cruz on Friday morning. According to Santa Cruz Fire Battalion Chief Todd Meyer, the residents were away at their second home at the time. Fire crews extinguished the blaze quickly, finding no victims or pets inside the house. Investigations into the cause of the fire are ongoing, and it comes shortly after a separate fire in November 2023 that resulted in the deaths of two pets in a nearby home.

title: Pius Fire burns almost 2,000 acres northeast of Payson; 77% contained
summary: The Pius Fire has burned nearly 2,000 acres northeast of Payson, Arizona, and is currently 77% contained. Starting in the Apache-Sitgreaves National Forests, the fire has prompted evacuation notices for areas around Bear Canyon Lake and a pre-evacuation status for Knoll Lake. Approximately 346 personnel, including air and ground crews, are working to control the blaze, which is being hindered by hot and dry conditions. The fire's cause remains unknown, and its smoke is visible from space, affecting nearby communities.

title: Forward progress stopped for a vegetation fire in North Monterey County Friday
summary: A vegetation fire measuring 1/3 acre ignited in North Monterey County on Friday due to sparks from a homeowner welding a fence. North County Fire quickly brought the fire under control, preventing further spread, and there was one structure at risk during the incident. Air crews were dispatched but were not needed for additional support.

title: Multiple fire agencies responding to a fire in the riverbed near San Lorenzo Park
summary: Multiple fire agencies are responding to a wildfire, named the Broadway Fire, burning in the riverbed near San Lorenzo Park in King City, California. The fire has spread to five acres, and Cal Fire is currently facing challenges in accessing the area. Residents are advised to avoid the vicinity as crews work to extinguish the flames. This is an ongoing situation.

title: Cal Fire battling wildfire burning east of Bradley
summary: Cal Fire is currently battling a wildfire east of Bradley in South Monterey County, California, which has the potential to expand to 150 acres. The fire has already burned approximately 5 to 10 acres and is threatening at least three structures. Firefighters are on the scene, with multiple engines and air support en route to combat the blaze. The situation is still developing.

title: Freeman Fire burns 32,568 acres north of Tucson; 85% contained
summary: The Freeman Fire in southern Arizona has burned approximately 32,568 acres and is currently 85% contained. Ignited by two lightning strikes that merged, the fire started in the Black Mountains, 16 miles south of Dudleyville. Crews have managed to contain the fire along several flanks, although it continues to threaten nearby infrastructure. Residents in Willow Springs Ranch are still under evacuation orders, and local traffic restrictions are in place on certain roads. High winds have hindered aerial firefighting efforts.

title: The dangers of Arizona’s abandoned mineshafts while fighting wildfires
summary: Arizona's abandoned mineshafts pose significant dangers for firefighters battling wildfires, as they can be difficult to spot and potentially fatal if someone falls in. With many mines dating back to before statehood, these shafts can exceed 100 feet in depth and may contain hazardous materials. Firefighters are working to map these mineshafts to improve safety during firefighting operations, although incidents of discovering old explosives are rare. If a firefighter does fall into a mineshaft, medical teams are typically equipped to rescue them.

title: Hillside Fire burns about 800 acres near Congress; 88% contained
summary: The Hillside Fire near Congress, Arizona, has burned approximately 818 acres and is now 88% contained. The fire is no longer threatening the community, and the Yavapai County Sheriff's Office has lifted the SET status for several zones. Roadblocks in the area are set to be removed by Friday evening. Firefighters are continuing to monitor the fire's perimeter, and the cause is believed to be lightning.

title: Arizona Humane Society sends team to help pets injured in the Watch Fire
summary: The Arizona Humane Society has deployed a disaster team to the San Carlos Apache Indian Reservation to assist with the medical care and sheltering of pets affected by the Watch Fire, which has caused significant damage and left many without homes. Currently, 15 dogs, six puppies, and three cats are receiving care at an evacuation center set up at the Apache Gold Casino & Resort. The fire has burned approximately 2,162 acres and is suspected to be caused by arson, with containment efforts still ongoing.

title: Wildfire risk rises as Western states dry out amid protracted heat wave
summary: Authorities in Western states are warning of an increased risk of wildfires due to a prolonged heat wave that has dried out landscapes and set temperature records. California has experienced over 3,500 wildfires this year, burning nearly 325 square miles, significantly above average. Fire crews are actively battling multiple blazes, including a large fire in Santa Barbara County that has prompted evacuations. Similar fire risks are present in Oregon and Washington, where officials have implemented burn bans to prevent sparks. Some relief is expected by the weekend as weather conditions shift.

title: Gemstone Fire burns 177 acres east of Kingman; 75% contained
summary: The Gemstone Fire, which began east of Kingman, Arizona, has burned approximately 177 acres and is currently 75% contained. The wildfire has threatened over 150 buildings and infrastructure, but no evacuations have been ordered. About 60 firefighters are working on the scene, and recent rain has aided containment efforts. The cause of the fire remains unknown.

title: Watch Fire grows to over 2,100 acres in eastern Arizona; arson suspected
summary: The Watch Fire in eastern Arizona has grown to over 2,162 acres, prompting the San Carlos Apache Tribe to declare a state of emergency and evacuate over 400 residents. The fire, suspected to be caused by arson, has destroyed at least 13 homes, leaving 75 people homeless. FEMA has authorized federal funds to assist in firefighting efforts, and Arizona Governor Katie Hobbs has allocated $400,000 to support the affected community. Tribal officials emphasize the need to document damage before cleanup and are determined to hold those responsible for the fire accountable.

title: Forward progress stopped as Butte Fire burns near Apache Lake in Tonto National Forest
summary: Firefighters are currently combating the Butte Fire, which ignited near Apache Lake in Tonto National Forest, Arizona, on Thursday evening. The blaze has burned approximately 117 acres and is 40% contained, with progress halted as of early Friday afternoon. The fire was caused by a lightning strike, and while nearby areas, including a marina and residences, are not currently threatened, Forest Road 79 was temporarily closed for firefighting access but has since reopened. Resources on the scene include multiple fire engines and a specialized hotshot crew.

title: Duck Lake fire burns 31 acres in eastern Arizona
summary: A slow-moving wildfire known as the Duck Lake fire has burned about 31 acres in eastern Arizona's Apache-Sitgreaves National Forests since it was discovered on July 5, reportedly caused by lightning. The fire is expected to consume dead vegetation from a previous burn site, and firefighting efforts include two fire engines aiming to contain the blaze within a designated perimeter. Currently, no homes are threatened, no evacuations have been ordered, and visitors are advised against camping in the area due to potential smoke visibility.

title: Pinal County residents return home as Ray Fire burns near Kearny
summary: Pinal County residents have been allowed to return home as firefighters have made significant progress in containing the Ray Fire near Kearny, which is now 100% contained along with the Shake Fire. The Ray Fire, human-caused and burning about 51 acres, prompted evacuation alerts for local mobile home communities earlier in the week, but those alerts have since been downgraded. The response included air tankers and hand crews from the Arizona Department of Forestry and Fire Management. Southbound State Route 177, which was closed due to the fire, has reopened.

title: Alleged firefighter impersonator accused of telling residents to evacuate due to Hillside Fire, causing panic
summary: A man named Patrick Parent is in custody after allegedly impersonating a firefighter and falsely telling residents in Yavapai County, Arizona, to evacuate due to the ongoing Hillside Fire, causing panic among the community. The Yavapai County Sheriff's Office confirmed that no official evacuations had been ordered and that Parent had been let go from the fire department months prior. He faces multiple charges, including DUI, impersonating a public servant, and disorderly conduct, after deputies found him driving with fire department clothing and obtained video evidence of his actions.

title: Residents return to ‘READY’ status as Shake Fire breaks out in Pinal County
summary: Residents in Kearny, AZ, have been returned to 'READY' status as firefighters successfully contained the Shake Fire and Ray Fire, both fully contained as of Thursday. The Shake Fire, which broke out on Tuesday and burned approximately 110 acres, was determined to be human-caused and was fueled by hot temperatures and dry conditions. The Pinal County Sheriff’s Office announced that all evacuation orders have been lifted, allowing residents to return home. Additionally, FEMA approved assistance to help cover firefighting costs.

title: Neighbors react to house fire that killed two pets in Santa Cruz
summary: A house fire in Santa Cruz over the weekend resulted in the deaths of two pets, a cat and a parrot, while the couple living in the home managed to evacuate safely. Neighbors witnessed the incident, with one resident recalling the chaos as flames engulfed the house. The fire, which primarily affected the second story, has been ruled accidental by the Santa Cruz Fire Department, and the couple declined assistance from the American Red Cross. Community members expressed their desire to support the couple in the aftermath of the tragedy.

title: Neighbors react to house fire that killed two pets in Santa Cruz
summary: A house fire in Santa Cruz on Sunday morning resulted in the deaths of two pets, a cat and a parrot, although there were no injuries to civilians or firefighters. Neighbors reported hearing screams and witnessing the flames, prompting a 911 call. The couple living in the home managed to self-evacuate before firefighters arrived. The fire, which destroyed much of the second story, has been deemed accidental, with no malicious intent. The American Red Cross offered assistance to the couple, but they declined help. Community members expressed their support and willingness to assist the couple in the aftermath.

title: Search location by ZIP code
summary: In St. Paul, Minnesota, a couple, Nate Meidel and Katie Faragher, faced a crisis when their home caught fire while they were out running errands, leaving their dog Pearl and cat inside. Firefighter Tim O'Neil discovered Pearl and, with the help of EMS, used a modified cup to deliver oxygen to her, helping her recover, although their cat did not survive. Grateful for the team's efforts, Meidel expressed his appreciation through a voicemail, later visiting them with Pearl to show his gratitude, highlighting the positive impact of their lifesaving actions.
